Stream<Provider<T>> TypeUtil.serviceProviderStream(ServiceLoader<T>) would return the stream of providers with exceptions etc.

replies.bodyText: @joakime our version actually works!   The ServiceLoader stream implementation has a bug, because it uses the iterator internally and does not protect against the cases that hasNext can throw.    If the JVM folks accept this is a bug and undertake to fix it, then we can deprecate the second option and eventually replace it.

I'm not sure we can avoid this with a Stream<Provider<T>> implemented in terms of an Iterator<T>.  There is no way to get the type from the iterator without getting the instance. I think we should probably just document the limitation and leave as is.  Ultimately we'd like to replace with a real JVM impl without the bug.

timeline.bodyText:
I don't think this is what we want.
Provider is a layer that delays the allocation of the service. Only when get() is called the allocation of the service happens.
This implementation allocates the service early and then wraps it into a Provider that does not "delay", so it changes the semantic of using a Provider.
It would be the same to have a Spliterator<T> at this point.
